prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of heavily obscured GRB host galaxies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Band 7 provides optimum sensitivity given the anticipated spectral index of our targets, and also permits us to spatially resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from VLT) shows it to be 1.3 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on the desire to crudely resolve the source (identify whether it is nucleus-dominated or distributed, localize regions of most active star-formation for comparison to the GRB position, look for merger signatures, etc.) while not sacrificing too much in sensitivity.

We are seeking a good S/N, partially-resolved detection of dust continuum from a GRB host galaxy at z~2. Based on our optical/NIR/Spitzer photometry, we estimate a minimum total flux of approximately 0.9 mJy (it may be more than this if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We do not know the distribution of the submillimeter flux on the host, but expect it to be spread over 5-10 resolution elements; we desire average S/N of ~3 per resolution element. This, and the desire to provide an accurate total flux regardless of the angular extent of the source in the millimeter band, motivates our target sensitivity.

This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of heavily obscured GRB host galaxies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Band 7 provides optimum sensitivity given the anticipated spectral index of our targets, and also permits us to spatially resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from HST) shows it to be 2.5 arcsec in total diameter (major axis; minor axis is about 0.5 arcsec), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on the desire to crudely resolve the source (identify whether it is nucleus-dominated or distributed, localize regions of most active star-formation for comparison to the GRB position, look for merger signatures, etc.) while not sacrificing too much in sensitivity.

We are seeking a good S/N, partially-resolved detection of dust continuum from a GRB host galaxy at z~2. Based on our optical/NIR/Spitzer photometry, we estimate a minimum total flux of approximately 1.1 mJy (it may be more than this if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We do not know the distribution of the submillimeter flux on the host, but expect it to be spread over 5-10 resolution elements; we desire average S/N of ~3 per resolution element. This, and the desire to provide an accurate total flux regardless of the angular extent of the source in the millimeter band, motivates our target sensitivity.

This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of heavily obscured GRB host galaxies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Band 7 provides optimum sensitivity given the anticipated spectral index of our targets, and also permits us to spatially resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from HST) shows it to be 2.2 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on the desire to crudely resolve the source (identify whether it is nucleus-dominated or distributed, localize regions of most active star-formation for comparison to the GRB position, look for merger signatures, etc.) while not sacrificing too much in sensitivity.

We are seeking a good S/N, partially-resolved detection of dust continuum from a GRB host galaxy at z~2. Based on our optical/NIR/Spitzer/Herschel/JVLA photometry, we estimate a total flux of approximately 2.5 mJy. We do not know the distribution of the submillimeter flux on the host, but expect it to be spread over 10-20 resolution elements; we desire average S/N of ~3 per resolution element. This, and the desire to provide an accurate total flux regardless of the angular extent of the source in the millimeter band, motivates our target sensitivity.

This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of heavily obscured GRB host galaxies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Band 7 provides optimum sensitivity given the anticipated spectral index of our targets, and also permits us to spatially resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from HST) shows it to be 0.9 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on the desire to crudely resolve the source (identify whether it is nucleus-dominated or distributed, localize regions of most active star-formation for comparison to the GRB position, look for merger signatures, etc.) while not sacrificing too much in sensitivity.

We are seeking a good S/N, partially-resolved detection of dust continuum from a GRB host galaxy at z~2. Based on our optical/NIR/Spitzer photometry, we estimate a minimum total flux of approximately 1.1 mJy (it may be more than this if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We do not know the distribution of the submillimeter flux on the host, but expect it to be spread over 5-10 resolution elements; we desire average S/N of ~3 per resolution element. This, and the desire to provide an accurate total flux regardless of the angular extent of the source in the millimeter band, motivates our target sensitivity.

This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of heavily obscured GRB host galaxies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Band 7 provides optimum sensitivity given the anticipated spectral index of our targets, and also permits us to spatially resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from HST) shows it to be 2.2 arcsec in total diameter (concentrated in three clumps of emission), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on the desire to crudely resolve the source (identify whether it is nucleus-dominated or distributed, localize regions of most active star-formation for comparison to the GRB position, look for merger signatures, etc.) while not sacrificing too much in sensitivity.

We are seeking a good S/N, partially-resolved detection of dust continuum from a GRB host galaxy at z~2. Based on our optical/NIR/Spitzer/Herschel/JVLA photometry, we estimate a total flux of approximately 1.8 mJy. We do not know the distribution of the submillimeter flux on the host; this host is larger than the others and it may potentially be spread over as many as 20 resolution elements, but the HST imaging already provides evidence that the source is likely to be quite clumpy (with most of the flux dispersed over fewer resolution elements in reality) and we aim for a similar sensitivity and resolution as our other targets.

This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of heavily obscured GRB host galaxies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Band 7 provides optimum sensitivity given the anticipated spectral index of our targets, and also permits us to spatially resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from VLT) shows it to be 1.6 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on the desire to crudely resolve the source (identify whether it is nucleus-dominated or distributed, localize regions of most active star-formation for comparison to the GRB position, look for merger signatures, etc.) while not sacrificing too much in sensitivity.

We are seeking a good S/N, partially-resolved detection of dust continuum from a GRB host galaxy at z~2. Based on our optical/NIR/Spitzer photometry, we estimate a minimum total flux of approximately 0.9 mJy (it may be more than this if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We do not know the distribution of the submillimeter flux on the host, but expect it to be spread over 5-10 resolution elements; we desire average S/N of ~3 per resolution element. This, and the desire to provide an accurate total flux regardless of the angular extent of the source in the millimeter band, motivates our target sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent observations have demonstrated that a substantial fraction of GRBs originate from heavily dust-obscured and luminous galaxies at z>1, a population that until recently was not thought to produce GRBs in significant numbers. This discovery has important implications for the connection between GRBs and the overall star-formation rate, suggesting that GRBs can occur in massive and dusty galaxies under certain conditions. We propose to obtain ALMA continuum observations of the ULIRG hosts of six GRBs at z~2 to directly measure their obscured star formation rates, resolve the structure of the hosts in dust emission, and determine whether the bursts originate from compact super-starbursts or more classical modes of star formation. These observations will fill a critical gap in our knowledge of the GRB population, identifying the physical conditions necessary to form GRBs in the high-redshift universe and providing new insight onto the nature of the GRB progenitor and its ability to probe conditions in the most dust-enshrouded galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
